bejegyzes.cim: Mass lay-offs planned at public broadcasters
bejegyzes.szoveg: A third of Hungary's public service media journalists will be laid off this year, of Hungary's new, centralized public service media institution, the MTVA. Meanwhile, the head of the Independent News Agency (FH) argues that plans for the national news agency MTI to supply public media with centrally prepared news bulletins constitutes a violation of the principle of free competition, and says he will take the case to the European Commission if necessary.

bejegyzes.cim: Thousands protest against new constitution
bejegyzes.szoveg: Facebook-organized demonstrations as Parliament prepares to vote on a new constitution.

bejegyzes.cim: Government says press freedom has limits
bejegyzes.szoveg: Zoltán Kovács, State Secretary for Government Communications, says that the government freedoms of the press and freedom of opinion, but that "local peculiarities" need to be taken into account when those principles are applied.

bejegyzes.cim: Hungary passes new constitution
bejegyzes.szoveg: Hungarian Parliament passes a new constitution in a vote along party lines. The far-right Jobbik party votes against the constitution, while the other opposition parties boycott the vote, saying that the new text eliminates the country's system of checks and balances and represents only the views of the governing Fidesz party. From the perspective of Fidesz, however, the , the party's election victory last year constituted "a revolution at the voting booths," and netted not just a two-thirds parliamentary majority but a mandate to overhaul the country's economy and legal foundations. The new constitution stipulates that numerous issues, including family policy and the tax and pension systems, will be specified in separate laws which can only be amended by a two thirds majority. The Hungarian Civil Liberties Union (HCLU) criticizes the new constitution, claiming it discriminates against those who do not share Christian-conservative values and enshrines the government's ideology into a legal doctrine that is devised to be extremely hard to amend.

bejegyzes.cim: UN Secretary-General weighs in on media laws
bejegyzes.szoveg: During a visit to Hungary, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon for its "remarkable" transformation from communism to democracy, but adds that Hungary's new media legislation should be "consistent with the legacy of your own fight for freedom and in tune with concerns in your neighborhood and around the world." Ki-Moon claims that "freedom of expression and the media are essential foundations for any healthy democracy."

bejegyzes.cim: German, Hungarian foreign ministries trade jabs
bejegyzes.szoveg: Hungarian foreign minister Zsolt Németh not to interfere in Hungary's domestic affairs, in response to German Deputy Foreign Minister Werner Hoyer's statement that Germany is "observing the developments in Hungary with great attention and not without concern." Hoyer criticized the new media legislation as incompatible with EU values, and added that "our worries over the media law are made worse, not better, by the adoption of the constitution." Németh responds by calling Hoyer's remarks "incomprehensible and unacceptable," and rejects Hoyer's reference to the media legislation as "particularly unacceptable."

bejegyzes.cim: Civil rights groups: new constitution weakens right to access to information
bejegyzes.szoveg: The new Hungarian constitution replaces the independent Data Protection and Freedom of Information Commissioner with an administrative authority with undetermined powers, according to human rights groups. Four organizations, including the Hungarian Civil Liberties Union (HCLU) and the South East Network for Professionalization of the Media (SEENPM), warn that this change could the right to access to information. "This move is a way to bring an immediate end to the independence of the existing information commissioner and replace him with a more subservient authority," says Helen Darbishire of Access Info Europe.

bejegyzes.cim: Hungary slides in Freedom House ranking
bejegyzes.szoveg: Hungary's ranking in an annual global press freedom report by international human rights organization Freedom House 65th,, from 40th in 2010. The report says that Hungary's slide in the ranking is a result of "the government's efforts to consolidate control over the country's independent institutions, including the creation of a new media council dominated by the ruling party that has the ability to impose large fines on broadcast, print, and online media outlets."

bejegyzes.cim: Council of Europe Commissioner calls EU-Hungary media amendment deal "unfortunate"
bejegyzes.szoveg: Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights Thomas Hammarberg that the deal between the Hungarian government and the European Commission to amend provisions in the media laws was "unfortunate," since the appearance of Brussels giving its “blessing” to the amended law undermined the message of his own office's report, which found there were still "serious flaws" in the legislation.

bejegyzes.cim: UN Human Rights Council questions Hungary over media law
bejegyzes.szoveg: Members of the UN Human Rights Council from the UK, Germany, Belgium and Holland over Hungary's media legislation. US delegate John C. Mariz calls the new laws "a departure from the Hungarian tradition of multi-party appointments to the media regulatory board, which raise concerns over strict regulation and limitations on freedom of expression." At the same time, representatives ask what measures Hungary plans to take to combat hate speech. Germany's human rights commissioner Markus Loening a German newspaper beforehand that the Hungarian media legislation was still full of "rules that contravene international standards."

bejegyzes.cim: Independent news agency gives up
bejegyzes.szoveg: The owners of independent news agency FH announce that it. The company, which produced some 150-200 broadcast-ready news items per day but never turned a profit, faced additional trouble now that the new media legislation tasked national news agency MTI with providing its news for free, to commercial as well as public media.

bejegyzes.cim: UN Rapporteur on freedom of expression returns to Hungary
bejegyzes.szoveg: Frank La Rue, The UN Special Rapporteur on freedom of opinion and expression, makes to Budapest for talks with the Hungarian government, and notes that Hungary's lawmakers disregarded several of the recommendations he'd made in April. He questioned the independence of the new Media Council, and said it could only become a creditable body when its decisions reflected the views of the opposition and civil society as well as the government parties.

bejegyzes.cim: Independent talk radio station under threat
bejegyzes.szoveg: The new Hungarian media authority that the FM frequency of talk radio station KlubRádió expired and is up for bid. During the past year, the authority had extended the station's license for three months at a time. KlubRádió, which draws 300,000 listeners a day from among opposition supporters, raised over 500,000 euro from its listeners to offset the loss of advertizing income it suffered as a consequence. Today's bid, however, calls for an applicant that will broadcast music and local news, which would seem to exclude KlubRádió. The station argues for political reasons.

bejegyzes.cim: Hungarian intellectuals write open letter to Hillary Clinton
bejegyzes.szoveg: A group of Hungarian intellectuals and former dissidents, including György Konrád and Miklós Haraszti, write to Hillary Clinton, who is to visit Hungary shortly. Arguing that "the rule of law has been seriously damaged in our country" under the new government, they specifically criticize the "omnipotent" new media authority, "composed solely of governing-party delegates, empowered to supervise not only broadcasting, but also the print and online media," which can impose "massive fines." They say "the public-service media were re-nationalized, and obliged to only use news provided by the state press agency."

bejegyzes.cim: Hillary Clinton meets Orban, expresses concern over free press, judiciary
bejegyzes.szoveg: After visiting Prime Minister Viktor Orban, U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton praises Hungary's economic reform and Roma initiatives, but says she Hungary's constitutional court, media laws and new constitution with Orban. "We ... talked very openly about preserving the democratic institutions of Hungary" and the need to safeguard "essential checks and balances," she said at a news conference with Orban. "As friends of Hungary we expressed our concerns and particularly call for a real commitment to the independence of the judiciary, a free press and governmental transparency."

bejegyzes.cim: Media Commissioner investigation into reader comments on newspaper site sparks concern
bejegyzes.szoveg: Media commissioner Jenő Bodonovich writes the left-wing newspaper Népszava to he is initiating an investigation into readers comments underneath an article, published on June 8, about President Schmitt and former President Mádl. The newspaper, which says it could not find out which remarks Bodonovich objected to specifically, recalls that the Media Council's spokeswoman previously said that reader comments do not fall under the media law. Media Council member Andras Koltay confirms in an interview on 3 July that the law does not apply to comments and fora, and only applies to content published after June 30. The announcement of the investigation, which Bodonovich initiated at the request of State Secretary Zoltan Kovacs, leads many news websites to close or curtail their comments sections.

bejegyzes.cim: One-third of public media workers to go
bejegyzes.szoveg: The director of the new, centralised public media funding and management body, the MTVA, announces that 550 of the 3,300 public media workers in August. A total of 1,000 will be dismissed by year end. The new media laws stipulate that all public media news bulletins are to be produced by the national news agency MTI, for newsroom staff at the public broadcasters. Green politician Gergely Karácsony said that people were being fired for not being loyal enough to the government in a "political purge". The MTVA argues that the old system was wasteful and opaque.

bejegyzes.cim: Parliament adopts further amendments to media laws
bejegyzes.szoveg: In its last session before the summer recess, Parliament adopts to the "Media Act" of 31 December 2010 and several other media and communications-related laws. One of them classifies unpaid fines imposed by the new media authority as public debt, meaning they can be collected by the tax authorities regardless of any legal challenge, and those who owe the fees are barred from frequency tenders. Another allows the NMHH, rather than an independent body, to define “public service”. A third amendment, however, seems responsive to criticisms of the new media laws. While the law had allowed unspecified "authorities" to oblige journalists to reveal their sources in “exceptionally justified cases” related to national security, public order and the prevention of crime, the amendment that only investigative authorities or a court can do so.
